title: Who will win the 2020 Nevada Democratic caucuses?
preds: Nevada is a popular state for Joe Biden but white male Bernie Sanders has momentum and appeal.

Biden's support continues to crumble, especially after a less than inspiring debate performance. Biden also tends to do worse than the poll projections, making a win in Nevada for win practically inconceivable.  Bernie is far ahead in the polls with close to double the amount of support of his competitors. Buttigieg tends to outperform polls, but it would e quite and upset if he managed to win.
New poll from Emerson College gives Sanders a 14 point lead. This pushes my prediction up a couple of points.
Nevada caucuses are only two days away, and Bernie has a double digit lead.
Looks like a lock for Bernie after yesterday's debate

I personally think the last debate will have a significant impact on the outcome of this primary. Because Elizabeth Warren came out “swinging” against Michael Bloomberg and I think she will see a rise in her numbers. Both Warren and “Mayor Pete” will see a significant rise in their numbers. Unfortunately, Amy Klobuchar will have the most negative impact from the last debate. I’m not sure if the list provided is correct so here is my predictions overall.  8% Joe Biden 23% Michael Bloomberg 26% Pete Buttigieg 3% Amy Klobuchar 32% Bernie Sanders 8% Elizabeth Warren 0% Someone else

Following the abject failure of my monte carlo model for the iowa caucuses, I've made a new one for Nevada. This model is much more refined, but the fatal issue for my iowa model was not taking account of the rural/urban divide in different candidates' votes, given the weighting towards rural voters in the delegate process. If anyone has data on rural/urban divides in different candidates' supports, let me know.

Biden's NV debate performance, by all accounts, left it more unclear why voters should back him.
"Being an alternative to Bernie" doesn't move the needle.

Update on Sanders prediction: Model - 77%
FiveThirtyEight - 76%
Exchange - 86% Weighted Average - 79%
So what did the debates do to the odds? I'm not sure but watching 5 Senators whomp on Poor Bloomberg - guess that was their version of "Stop and Frisk" - And jump initiation into their gang?
Based on impressions of the 2/19 debate.
I’m late to party in Nevada. Go Bernie!

Sanders is the clear leader with Union members, Spanish speakers,  he is solid with African Americans and women.  His supporters have the passion to be involved.  It would be a stunning upset if anyone else surpasses him in Nevada.

Sanders has a commanding and increasing lead in a variety of polls.
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/nevada/

270toWin, 538 and RealClear Politics aggregations: 
Bernie Sanders more than 25% 
Nobody else near 20% (Biden 2nd +15%)

There have been three more polls since my last forecast which give Sanders an average lead of 6-7%. My model suggests this gives Sanders around a 70% chance of winning. As expected, with Sanders poll lead holding FiveThirtyEight (69%) and the exchange markets (84%) are now more confident of a Sanders victory. I suspect the markets prediction is a little high considering how unpredictable Nevada is and how Sanders results so far have been unconvincing.

The failure of the Culinary Union to endorse any candidate is a blow to Biden - not to mention the recent Las Vegas Review-Journal polling putting him in second place to Bernie.
In my readings, I found an assertion that Biden has never won a presidential primary - and that seems to be true. There is nothing that I see where NV 2020 will be the first win for Biden.
Open field running for Bernie at this point..
I gave zero chance for a Mike Bloomberg surprise b/c I found NV law does now allow write-ins.
While not entirely sure about this prohibition for caucuses - as they are private party affairs - I figure they must follow state rules and voted accordingly.

IOWA: Buttgieg, Bernie
NEW HAMPSHIRE: Bernie, Buttgieg Therefore S.E with good %

The momentum Bernie is gaining with pledged endorsements from an impressive list of organizations (not to mention polls, individual donations and huge rallies) feels like a solid indicator that Bernie has the strongest shot at Nevada, and possibly beyond.

latest poll finds Bernie a full 19 points ahead of anyone else and Steyer's support stalled at around 10%, and without a large number of respondents choosing other.  Biden's support has continued to dwindle down to the teens, making it nearly impossible for him to win.

Nevada should be good for Bernie demographically and he got this endorsement https://www.politico.com/news/2020/02/18/national-latino-group-endorses-bernie-sanders-115712 But caucuses are harder to forecast on than primaries... https://www.politico.com/news/2020/02/18/joe-biden-nevada-campaign-critics-115723, https://www.politico.com/news/2020/02/17/bernie-sanders-nevada-breaks-pack-115450

latest polls have Sanders 10 or 19 points ahead of his nearest competitor. Biden and Buttigieg are presently close to tied for second, depending upon the poll. The polls that has Sanders 19 points ahead seems to be an outlier, but there will be a new PBS poll in the morning. https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/latest_polls/state_democratic_nomination_polls/
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-primary-d/nevada/

Adjusting to consider the emerging diversity of Sanders's support and recent models:
https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/nevada/
Caucases favour organised campaigns (Bernie). None of the other named candidates have big momentum, so a shock win would come from a complete dark horse (mayor pete, klobucher...)

Warren's support has continually dropped since January and is holding steady at around 10%. Therefore, it is completely unforeseeable that her support could more than double in the next few days.  Neither Buttigieg nor Klobuchar have much mobilization in Nevada and the latest poll shows them at only 10%, it is likely that this support will grow on election day, especially with a good debate performance and a bad performance by Biden. Therefore, it's possible one of them is able to break away and it's hard to understand how much support they really have due to a lack of polling.  Tom Steyer is a little bit of a dark horse as he has really been in the race, but has focused on Nevada and South Carolina, however polls show significant support for Steyer and so it foreseeable that he is able to come out of the woodwork with a surprise win in Nevada, especially considering  the lack of polling could be under representing his support. Biden still is polling decently in Nevada, although support has significantly dropped since his terrible Iowa and NH performance. However, it can be assured that Biden's campaign is pushing hard for a good finish in Nevada, while other campaigns are likely going to cut their losses there i.e. Warren, Klobuchar and Buttigieg and start focusing on the Super Tuesday States. Biden's support however has typically been over represented by polls, and the polls in the past month have shown him at under 20%, when around 25% is needed to win a state. But he could still possibly win Nevada, a good debate performance is key though.  The latest poll does show Bernie winning at above the margin of error and with support at the crucial 25% mark. Moreover, Bernie has the momentum going into Nevada and has a huge operating staff there that will easily be able to out canvass any other candidate. Moreover, when voting statistics from Iowa and NH are broken down, Bernie captures a surprising majority of hispanic voters, who are of course a huge demographic in Nevada. Therefore, as is typically the case with minorities and polling data, it is likely that Bernie's support in the polls is underrepresented.
Adjusting slightly, narrowing the playing field but still favoring Sanders.

The latest poll in this state gives Sanders a 7 point lead over Joe Biden. My model suggests this translates to a 65% chance of Sanders winning the nomination for this state. I'm going to downgrade to 60% though as the polls in Iowa and New Hampshire seem to have overestimated Sanders popularity and underestimated Buttigieg's. My overall forecast incorporates predictions from other sources. FiveThirtyEight more or less mirror my own forecast (66%) while the betting exchanges are much more confident of a Sanders victory at 75%. With these forecasts in mind I'm going to push my own Sanders forecast up to 64%. We really need more polling in Nevada though before I can make a forecast I have confidence in. The one published yesterday by WPA was the first this month so we only have a fairly shallow insight into what peoples intentions are in this state.

Fivethirtyeight model [1] currently gives Sanders 64 percent chance of winning the Nevada caucuses, Biden 16 percent, Buttigieg10 percent and Warren 7 percent. [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-biden-hasnt-exactly-collapsed-since-new-hampshire/

Fivethirtyeight model [1] currently gives Sanders 64 percent chance of winning the Nevada caucuses, Biden 16 percent, Buttigieg10 percent and Warren 7 percent. [1] https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/election-update-biden-hasnt-exactly-collapsed-since-new-hampshire/
Bernie will not win, even though it’s a caucus, Bernie has not beaten Mayor Pete yet.

Biden and Sanders should both do well here, with Biden having an edge with minorities and Sanders perhaps with an edge among union voters.  Buttigieg, Bloomberg and Klobuchar will split the remainder of the centrist vote, Steyer will have some name recognition there, but not enough to make a difference, and Warren will lose out on the liberal vote to Sanders.
Bloomberg will finally get more recognition.
Mike Bloomberg. I believe he has the ideas and forethought to gather the strength of voters that he needs.

Adjusting to brace for Nevada's uncertainty and historic unpredictability (e.g. major groups supporting one candidate and flipping when it comes time to vote.) Biden is on the edge of momentum that could tip in either direction. Support for Sanders is a major uncertainty.
538 says Sanders up and Biden down.
In the absence of a Culinary Workers' Union endorsement, I'm back up on Sanders.

The Culinary Workers Union, which is the largest union in Nevada, is not endorsing anyone as of today [1] - though note that the union leadership has clearly expressed its opposition to Sanders and his medicare-for-all plan [2]. Unfortunately, there has been no polling of Nevada since Jan. 14 [3]. The results of the most recent poll on Jan. 14 (conducted by Suffolk University, which has an A+ rating from FiveThirtyEight) showed Biden at 19%, Sanders at 18%, Warren at 11%, Buttigieg at 8%, and Steyer at 8% [4]. In terms of second-choice preference (which is important because Nevada has a caucus system where a 15% threshold must be reached for viability): Warren is at 21%, Biden is at 19%, and Sanders is at 12% [4].  Given his recent victories in Iowa and New Hampshire, Sanders has probably surpassed Biden - though Biden almost certainly remains very competitive. Warren and Buttigieg are probably also competitive, though to to a lesser extent. My understanding of the situation largely aligns with the probabilities that FiveThirtyEight's model gives (Sanders 71% Biden 16%, Buttigieg 11%, Warren 7%), though with less strength given to Sanders's position due to his campaign's spat with the Culinary Workers Union. FiveThirtyEight's model [5]: Sanders at 71%, Biden at 16%, Buttigieg at 11%, Warren at 7%. [1] https://thehill.com/policy/healthcare/483022-nevadas-culinary-union-wont-endorse-before-primary
[2] https://www.politico.com/news/2020/02/12/bernie-sanders-nevada-culinary-union-114687
[3] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/nevada/
[4] https://www.suffolk.edu/news-features/news/2020/01/13/22/19/poll-shows-biden-and-sanders-on-top-in-nevada
[5] https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2020-primary-forecast/nevada/

The Culinary Workers' Union leadership is holding a press conference in Las Vegas in about 45 minutes. It will be interesting to see if they endorse a candidate. Whoever picks up their endorsement will have a very sophisticated organization backing them. https://www.motherjones.com/politics/2018/10/what-the-democratic-party-can-learn-from-nevada-casino-workers-cooks-and-housekeepers/
Based on FiveThirtyEight's forecast, adjusting to give higher probabilities to the two main contenders.

8 runners give everyone a start of 12.5% random pick chance. From there we can see where the momentum has been flowing PB + BS - JB- EW - AK+. We can then take into account polling number averages and the potential Bloomberg effect. Add time until Saturday, and we have a race between PB, BS and JB.
Amy will take it. Most centrist of all Democrats.
Mayor Pete or Klobachar have real chances here.
Most Dems from Nevada are quite young and recent transplants.

The polls say Biden but momentum says Sanders. Polls can be misleading though, because I wonder how many people fear the stigma of claiming to vote for a "democratic socialist." 
Biden is having difficulty staying on message, question is, does the white, rural vote see him as a viable challenger to Trump.
Warren appears to be retreating in NV and SC to live to fight another state... either showing confidence or frugality. https://www.270towin.com/2020-democratic-nomination/nevada-caucus
https://www.masslive.com/politics/2020/02/elizabeth-warren-pulls-ads-in-nevada-south-carolina-amid-fundraising-push-and-long-haul-for-democratic-nomination.html

The Culinary Union has attacked Sanders' Medicare-for-All proposal. Ordinarily something like this might not matter much, but Nevada is a caucus state, and organization counts. Buttigieg is on record as being against Medicare-for-All, so I suppose it's possible he can edge out Sanders by a delegate or two, as he did in Iowa. This might have been Warren's big chance, but she's even more gung-ho for Medicare-for-All than Sanders is.
warren may have a chance to show her organizational skills
Bernie Sanders has gotten the most votes out of the two races thus far. His base is loyal, and the rest of the field seems fragmented.

Or is it just based on his support from black support?
Joe: It will diminish in a matter of days if you keep doing same. Incumbent is juggernaut, play very dirty, has unbelievable base support, lot of support from many parts of government (national and local), help from Russia, and fact is he wants it more than before!
Almost certainly Sanders,  but giving a small nod to Buttigieg's chances.
Base Rates from 538  //adjusted for Biden's unimpressive tally in Iowa and NH, plus Warren and Klob's better than aexpected run
538 have Sanders and Biden in a tie. The plates seem to be shifting with Mayor Pete, Klobuchar and Bloomberg gaining traction. Dems are looking for most electable.
I think it is too early to write off Biden.

Taking the results of the 2020 Iowa caucus by demographic group, Bernie Sanders appears poised to win Nevada if he carries similar percentages as in Iowa. According to the U.S. census, Nevada's slightly younger, less educated, and significantly more Hispanic population all favors Sanders. Coming out of Iowa, Sanders' main rival is Pete Buttigieg ("someone else" in this forecast), but his poor showing among Hispanic Iowans does not bode well for his chances in Nevada. Joe Biden, another potential rival to Sander's in Nevada is leading in the polls, but there has not been a new poll in almost a month. Biden did terribly in Iowa and looks to do even worse in New Hampshire. He will have no momentum and dwindling money going into Nevada. Sanders barely lost Nevada in 2016.
https://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2020/president/nv/nevada_democratic_presidential_caucus-6866.html
https://www.census.gov/quickfacts/fact/table/IA,NV/PST045219
https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/02/03/us/elections/results-iowa-caucus-polls.html
https://www.cnn.com/election/2016/primaries/polls/nv/Dem

In the 14 primary polls compiled on Wikipedia since Biden announces his candidacy in April of last year, Joe Biden leads in 11 of them, with Bernie Sanders within a few % each time while leading in two of the polls, the last and most recent poll going to "undecided". Sanders has slowly been gaining as Biden's polling has been dropping. As of now it seems that Sanders will win Iowa, but if polling is to be trusted, Biden will win by a slight margin unless Sanders' victory in Iowa is enough of a push to turn the moderates toward the left.

FiveThirtyEight polls currently have Biden leading, but that may drop after the Iowa caucus results, the polls for which had Sanders leading slightly, which may lower Biden's chances slightly. Additionally, because Warren has dropped steadily over the past month in polls her chances may lessen as the month continues. Steyer and Buttigieg do not have enough momentum in the polls to counter Sanders or Biden. Lastly, in the 2016 election, Sanders slowly caught up to Clinton and the final polls had Sanders with considerable support.

Polling trends show Bernie narrowly winning Iowa and solidly taking New Hampshire, the first two states. Biden has the softest support among voters, who may move away from him if he loses the first two states. Biden's supporters second choice is split between Bernie and Warren. If Biden pulls through in Iowa, he has a decent shot at taking Nevada, but it's a union-heavy state with high Latino population which bodes well for Bernie.

Hillary won Nevada in 2016, 52.64% to Bernie's 47.29%. 
Current polls show Biden 24.2%, Sanders 22.4%, Warren 13.5%.
538 says Biden 24 and Sanders 21. If Sanders wins Iowa he might come up more but Nevada generally is conservative so maybe woukd not go
